job_title: Library Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Excellent place to work at. Very peaceful
cons: Most of the work requires physical

pros: Generous vacation time, 401K is great, Generous sick time. Tech team within the group are helpful for the most part. Supervisor (manager) staff was initially in poor shape in terms of turnover, but has improved.
cons: Faculty need basic computer training, onboarding of faculty in terms of classroom tech is mediocre--which make it harder on technicians to do their jobs. Example: A classroom call came in reporting an issue with the computer in the classroom--the new faculty member did not know how to turn the computer on from the button after it was shut down by a previous user. Office staff can be unprofessional at times in other departments, IT upper management not in touch with technicians, low pay in comparison to market pay. Reviews are a joke and is not a factor in terms of pay raises. No room from growth at all.

review_title: Not worth it unless a second job
job_title: Help Desk Technician in Patchogue, NY
pros: The work-life balance is great. You get insane amount of PTO and says off almost close to 45 days a year. Benefits are great as well. 7% contribution from employer for 403B. The salary is the only downside. You make 45k a year. You work 35 hours a week.
cons: Benefits PTO Less hours Easy going

job_title: Client Services Technician in Brooklyn, NY
pros: St. Joseph's has a wonderful community that's diverse, inclusive and compassionate. Also the commute is fast for me since the Brooklyn campus is two blocks from a subway stop. Free undergrad tuition is a great perk as well.
cons: Like the title said, I wish the salary was higher so I can actually live off of it. That's the only con of my job.

review_title: Toxic, Highly Political, They Do Not Care About You
pros: - Lot of paid time off, that's about it.
cons:
- Leftist toxic people who only care about their own salaries rather than building up the college and their employees.
- If you speak out in opposition of their leftist agenda they are forcing down on everyone at the college, you will be marked and eventually terminated.
- HR does not care to provide real info/responses, they are reading from a script to continue pushing a leftist agenda at the college.
- Superiors take absolutely no responsibility for their actions, yet have no problem taking the absurdly large salaries that come with the title.
- Superiors pretend like they care, but when push comes to shove will gladly throw you and any other employees under the bus to protect their own absurdly large paycheck.
- Superiors claim to do what's best for the community and the students, when in fact they are doing the exact opposite to line their own pockets because they know the ship is sinking.
- HR will lie to help push the leftist agenda down on employees and students.
- HR is on some leftist power trip. You are not fooling anyone, you are HR at an over glorified community college, not an ivy league university, stop playing politics.
- President Boomgaarden is a leftist fascist quack with no real experience, destroying the college and it's reputation, while collecting over $500,000+ a year.
- President Boomgaarden is heavily involved with politics and using the college as a stepping stone for his own leftist agenda: Google politicsny top 100 power players in education (glassdoor would not let me share link)
- No one is willing to speak out because they are in it for the money and/or lack backbone.
- Covid Response Team is a self appointed joke of quacks playing politics with peoples health and livelihoods. HR director D'adra Crump and CIO Michelle Papajohn both lie about their involvement. Crump even has it listed on her Linkedin but then states HR is not involved. Your lies can only get you so far before people get fed up with your fascist BS.
- Morale is nonexistent. Everyone knows the sick games occurring and looking to jump ship and/or collect for the least amount of work possible.

pros:
They pay on time and understand when you have a family emergency or emergency situation
they are getting new leadership within different departments
cons:
They try to do everything in there power not to give you a raise and work extra

pros: Great community of students, faculty and staff.  Staff and Deans are very helpful, stay connected and provide timely information.  They are very supportive and always willing to help.
cons: Silos and turf wars in academic advisement, admissions and some of the other departments.

pros: I was sent to St. Joseph's College to do an temporary assignment and I end up getting hired permanently. I have learned a lot since being employed here.  You can also go to the college for free to pursue your masters degree.
cons: The salary was not on par with other colleges.
